Answer: “What are some arguments against advanced technology?”The usual argument is “It will eliminate my job.”This isn’t a silly argument. Economic changes, including those flowing from new technologies, do create losers as well as winners. Pretending otherwise is dishonest. Focusing only on the winners and ignoring the losers is dishonest. And leaving the losers high and dry is bad for your economy and your society.This doesn’t mean technology should be banned. It doesn’t mean economic changes should be banned. It means we should think about people’s jobs being eliminated. We should expect these cha“What are some arguments against advanced technology?”The usual argument is “It will eliminate my job.”This isn’t a silly argument. Economic changes, including those flowing from new technologies, do create losers as well as winners. Pretending otherwise is dishonest. Focusing only on the winners and ignoring the losers is dishonest. And leaving the losers high and dry is bad for your economy and your society.This doesn’t mean technology should be banned. It doesn’t mean economic changes should be banned. It means we should think about people’s jobs being eliminated. We should expect these changes and have plans for coping.An ideal coping mechanism is education, especially K-12 that provides the skills for more than one job. This is the opposite of “I grew up in a mining town; mining is the only job I’ve ever had; it’s the only job I’m qualified for; now what am I gonna do?”Another ideal coping mechanism is a diversified economy. It’s the opposite of “This is a mining town. Everyone works for the mine or supplies something for the miners.”Since not everyone gets a good education and not every economy is diverse, we also need safety net programs. Those need improvement. Especially job retraining programs, especially those that say, “You should learn to program, move from West Virginia to Silicon Valley, and find a job. I’m sure that will work great.”

Answer: It is humanity and existence, privacy and security, and mass technological unemployment.The rise of big data and the power of narrow AIs as machine learning techniques are the greatest risk to our privacy and security.We have a number of exponential technologies lead by big data analytics and narrow AI, machine learning and deep learning.1 – Virtual assistants/software agents delivering information and automating tasks.2– Human augmentation (cyborgs).3 – Automation technology, jobs will be destroyed.4 – Big data techniques for handling large volumes of personal data.5 – Biotechnology to cloneIt is humanity and existence, privacy and security, and mass technological unemployment.The rise of big data and the power of narrow AIs as machine learning techniques are the greatest risk to our privacy and security.We have a number of exponential technologies lead by big data analytics and narrow AI, machine learning and deep learning.1 – Virtual assistants/software agents delivering information and automating tasks.2– Human augmentation (cyborgs).3 – Automation technology, jobs will be destroyed.4 – Big data techniques for handling large volumes of personal data.5 – Biotechnology to clone human beings and edit genomes, reduce aging process, build human parts, replace defective organs and tissues.6 – Blockchain to hide or protect your security and privacy.7 – Cybersecurity/IT security, Cybercriminals target customers’ personally identifiable information (PII) - names, addresses, national identification numbers (e.g., Social Security numbers in the U.S., fiscal codes in Italy), credit card information - and then sell these records in underground digital marketplaces.8 – Smart city technologies using face recognition systems for mass surveillance or electronic Internet of Things (IoT) sensors to collect data and then use this data to manage assets and resources efficiently.9 – Quantum computing.10 – Cloud computing, private, public and hybrid cloud as software as a service (SaaS), platform as a service (PaaS) or infrastructure as a service (IaaS).11 – Drones, unmanned aerial vehicles that have a wide variety of shapes, sizes and characteristics backed by cloud services and big data techniques.12 – Hologram, digital cameras, display technologies, high-speed Internet connectivity, VR. AR.13 – 3D printing to manufacture high-precision products within the industrial world.14 – Brain-computer interface to expand our sensory, physical and intellectual capacities through technological implants.15 – Internet of Things (IoT), through the Internet, anything can be connected, from sensors and mechanical devices to everyday objects.16 – Nanotechnology manipulation of matter on an atomic, molecular and supramolecular scale. Their goal is to create cleaner, better, cheaper, and smarter products.17 – Virtual and augmented reality, a computer generated interactive experience that takes place in a simulated environment or a real-world environment where objects are enhanced by computer-generated perceptual information, through multiple sensory modalities.18 – Advanced robotics,, industrial robots and service robots.19 – Autonomous vehicles imitating human capacities for handling and control, perceiving the external environment and navigating without human interference at automation level 5.20 - Metaverse, a simulated world of superintelligent agents and digital humans.

Answer: This was Timothy Evans:He was a Welsh man who, had he grown up and attended school contemporarily, would have been dubbed “special needs”. Not only did he struggle academically, but lost much of his schooling due to illness, and ended up leaving school barely even able to read or write.In 1948, he moved into 10 Rillington Place, Notting Hill with his pregnant wife. Notting Hill then was not the affluent area that it became decades later, but just another dingy post-war slum. A place mostly made up of poor but decent people trying to maintain some semblance of dignity after escaping the blitz.SThis was Timothy Evans:He was a Welsh man who, had he grown up and attended school contemporarily, would have been dubbed “special needs”. Not only did he struggle academically, but lost much of his schooling due to illness, and ended up leaving school barely even able to read or write.In 1948, he moved into 10 Rillington Place, Notting Hill with his pregnant wife. Notting Hill then was not the affluent area that it became decades later, but just another dingy post-war slum. A place mostly made up of poor but decent people trying to maintain some semblance of dignity after escaping the blitz.Shortly after moving in, Timothy’s wife Beryl gave birth to a little girl. Even though they struggled immensely—Timothy’s difficulties made it hard for him to hold down a job, his wife wasn’t very good at managing their funds—they seemed to scrape on by. A year later though, things got dicey when Beryl found herself pregnant again. They couldn’t afford another baby and abortion was illegal at the time, so what were they to do? That’s where fellow tenant and wannabe landlord John Christie stepped in, claiming to have knowledge on how to do an abortion and offering to help the couple. Desperate and vulnerable, they accepted.Whilst Timothy was elsewhere, Christie strangled, raped and killed this 19 year old pregnant woman. Then he strangled their 13 month old baby, Geraldine. Christie framed Timothy for the murders and the widowed father ended up hanging for crimes he did not commit.This flesh and blood human being whose only crime was being vulnerable, this flesh and blood human being who had everything taken from him — his wife, his infant daughter and his unborn son, had his life stolen from him for no good reason. He had to endure the fear, the pain and the injustice of his position until the rope snapped his innocent neck.If that’s not good enough reason to do away with the death penalty, I don’t know what is.

Answer: It is a great shortcoming of human conciousness that we don't (or no longer) experience ourselves as intimately connected aspects of the wider process of life on this planet. Our gift as sentient beings is that we can control ourselves and our environment with mathematical precision, but this is also our curse. We are simultaneously very intelligent, but not intelligent enough to fully understand the infinitely complicated symbiotic processes that sustain us and all life, and how we are impacting them.Thus, we talk of this planet as if it is 'ours' and exploit its resources as such, not realisIt is a great shortcoming of human conciousness that we don't (or no longer) experience ourselves as intimately connected aspects of the wider process of life on this planet. Our gift as sentient beings is that we can control ourselves and our environment with mathematical precision, but this is also our curse. We are simultaneously very intelligent, but not intelligent enough to fully understand the infinitely complicated symbiotic processes that sustain us and all life, and how we are impacting them.Thus, we talk of this planet as if it is 'ours' and exploit its resources as such, not realising that the whole biosphere is a very finely balanced network of contained conflicts, of which we are but a very influential part. In doing so we are destabilising the environment and atmosphere that sustain us in the name of 'human progress'. We are like a starving man cutting off his own arm today so that he may be sure he won't go hungry tomorrow. Because we feel ourselves to be seperate from the wider course of nature, our attempts to survive at all costs are peculiarly self-destructive.

Answer: Simply, things that situate right above your head that you cannot see--Satellite technology.  This tech is classified in the category of science of electromagnetic field--which means that it operates mainly on waves that can be expanded across the electromagnetic spectrum.Since electromagnetic waves (a.k.a. microwaves) travel a speed of light, cannot be seen, felt or detected by any human ability without the assistance of another special technology, and can permeate through anything, such as human body, walls, ceilings, underground and underwater, any military weapon like satellite technologSimply, things that situate right above your head that you cannot see--Satellite technology.  This tech is classified in the category of science of electromagnetic field--which means that it operates mainly on waves that can be expanded across the electromagnetic spectrum.Since electromagnetic waves (a.k.a. microwaves) travel a speed of light, cannot be seen, felt or detected by any human ability without the assistance of another special technology, and can permeate through anything, such as human body, walls, ceilings, underground and underwater, any military weapon like satellite technology that features these characteristics becomes the ultimate.  Furthermore, satellite sits in the space where no one can see and monitor its activities and where no governance of human law exists.  This geographic point of advantage gives it the most freedom of will.  This is why the U.S. government has been continuously investing in the expansion of space program ever since it was first developed in the 1950's by a group of German immigrant scientists.Satellite was first conceived primarily to serve the U.S. military purpose of  surveying the ground activities of the Communist Russians.  Its civil applications only came secondarily years later and very often is used as a mean to mask its military uses (that's why most of us know so little about this).Satellite technology has the unsurpassed capabilities of reading, controlling and manipulating human body, mind, attitudes and behaviors.  Since it works on electromagnetic energy and human body is a walking circuit and human brain also operates on microwaves, its ability to intimately interface and interact with human body and mind is incredibly sophisticated...unimaginable by anyone.  It can easily operate a human much like a fashion of a zombie with the speed of light.  It can produce mass human destruction...far beyond the nuclear capability... in term of speed, magnitude and expansiveness.  In term of being a weapon of destruction and spying, satellite technology is the unmatched well-kept jewel of the U.S. government ever developed in the history of man.  In the civil setting, it permeates almost every aspect of life on earth.  In addition to its interfacing ability with human brain and body, it can interface with all  electronic devices such as computer, ATM and mobile phone.  It can access into anything that is digital.  It can also easily disenable any of these devices in split seconds.Now, if you stand back and gather all the information provided above and project that into a large integrated picture, you will realize how unimaginably powerful satellite technology is in the setting of military, politics and economics.  The limit of this satellite technology in the technology-and-human relationship is only bound to the creativity  and imagination of an human satellite operator.P.s. If satellite technology can do numbers of things on human that are only to be limited by the will and creativity of its human operator and no one would ever know about this, would you think that the U.S. government  dares to use this technology to monitor and spy on the activities of its civilians right in their homes and turn its citizens into zombies in order to put forth various large scale economic and political agendas.  If a human can be controlled and manipulated into any possible form of biological states that a human body can possibly respond, such as going from being healthy to sickness, without ever being known, then he or she can be ruthlessly turned into an economic commodity to promote various economic industries that links to healthcare.

Answer: In 2003 I was working for Cisco Systems and at the time we learned that the US Department of Defense had worked with Intel and other chip manufacturers to install in their hardware the ability to remotely disable any device using their technology with a certain radio frequency. Supposedly, this technology was used to help cripple the Iraqi air defense system when the US invaded.This was important to Cisco because we were working in security and cryptography and the NSA was forever trying to get us to corrupt our products so they could un-encrypt foreign transmissions on the fly. One time we weIn 2003 I was working for Cisco Systems and at the time we learned that the US Department of Defense had worked with Intel and other chip manufacturers to install in their hardware the ability to remotely disable any device using their technology with a certain radio frequency. Supposedly, this technology was used to help cripple the Iraqi air defense system when the US invaded.This was important to Cisco because we were working in security and cryptography and the NSA was forever trying to get us to corrupt our products so they could un-encrypt foreign transmissions on the fly. One time we were required to corrupt product that had been shipped to China and it started a major debate about our fiduciary responsibility to the country or to the customer. The issue was that if you sell a security product that you know is corrupted, you are knowingly committing fraud and are liable. As the Product Manager at the time I asked the NSA if they would stand behind us (and me as I might be personally liable) in court if we were discovered. Of course the answer from the NSA was “Hell no.”We were on our own. We then entered into a long debate about how to detect Easter eggs and other corruption introduced into security products unknowingly through another vendor’s corrupted hardware. The issue was never resolved but it should be known that our security source code HAD to be provided to the NSA in order to get FIPS certification and they made certain changes to it.So to answer your question, USA military technology is advanced far beyond anyone’s knowledge to describe the extent.On the other hand, the Chinese probably know more about our technology than we do since they perpetrated the greatest security breach in history by compromising the RSA key technology used by almost everyone in the world. We only learned of it through the vigilance of Lockheed-Martin who discovered the breach accidentally. But for months the Chinese had the key to almost every computer in the world.

The hydration pack the military uses was invented by a bicyclist who tired of grabbing water bottles while riding. The military only adopted it after soldiers kept purchasing the packs themselves.The Army developed paratroopersThe military developed GPS, but the civilian sector took the technology and put it into small handheld devices for hikers and hunters. The military rejected the idea at first. When soldiers began buying the units themselves the military got interested.The MOLLE pack was derived from gear used by firefighters.Civilian hikers have access to lightweight and warm clothing the military still has not adopted. The cost of outfitting a couple million troops outweighs the advantage of the better clothing.Private sector hiker/camper food is lighter and more nutritious than MREs, as well cheaper per meal. It does not have the shelf life of MREs, so the military has not adopted it.

Answer: When my son and I visited China in the year 2000 part of our tour was to the then-under construction Three Gorges Dam. The project was of particular interest to we Canadians because China had bought two massive electrical generators to install in the dam. As part of the deal, China required that they have the technology rights to produce copies of those generators (technology transfer agreements) and they successfully did so to produce the many other generators required.I believe that many purchases by China of out-of-country technology has the technology transfer agreement written into the coWhen my son and I visited China in the year 2000 part of our tour was to the then-under construction Three Gorges Dam. The project was of particular interest to we Canadians because China had bought two massive electrical generators to install in the dam. As part of the deal, China required that they have the technology rights to produce copies of those generators (technology transfer agreements) and they successfully did so to produce the many other generators required.I believe that many purchases by China of out-of-country technology has the technology transfer agreement written into the contract. This does not meet the definition of “stealing” but seems to be a very shrewd business practice that benefits China for the long term future.
name: Tim Brown
